clinical_study.brief_title: The Use of Near Infrared Spectroscopy in the Diagnosis of Acute Compartment Syndrome in Injured Soldiers
clinical_study.official_title: The Use of Near Infrared Spectroscopy in the Diagnosis of Acute Compartment Syndrome in Injured Soldiers

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to define the reliability and accuracy of Near Infrared Spectroscopy (NIRS) in the detection of intra-compartmental tissue perfusion in injured and noninjured extremities over time. The investigators hypothesize that this technology, combined with vital signs, intracompartmental pressures and clinical examinations, will be useful in diagnosing acute compartment syndrome (ACS), monitoring patients at risk for ACS, and evaluating the adequacy of fasciotomy in patients treated for ACS.

primary_outcome.measure: NIRS values in various physiologic states (stable control, critically injured control, lower extremity injury)

arm_group.description: Uninjured soldiers to provide normative data for stable physiological status

Critically injured soldiers with no lower extremity traumatic injuries (excepting skin abrasions and small/superficial fragmentation wounds) to provide normative data for the "shock" physiological status.
Soldiers with severe traumatic lower extremity injuries in stable and shock physiologic status. This is the investigational cohort.

intervention.description: Non-invasive monitoring device applied on the surface of the skin that emits harmless red light to measure tissue perfusion.

study_pop.textblock: Active duty OIF/OEF military personnel who have been air evacuated from theater to Landstuhl Regional Medical Center (LRMC). Ambulatory, self-care volunteers from the LRMC outpatient spine center will be identified to serve as controls for Cohort 1.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 18-65 years old
- male or female
- active duty servicemen who have been evacuated from OIF or OEF through LRMC
Exclusion Criteria:
- patients not willing to provide consent
- patients in whom application of NIRS monitoring is viewed as an impediment to casualty care
